Starting out in R&D
item.description: <p>Upon leaving University, I joined <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/company/csiro/">CSIRO</a> and was thrown straight in the deep-end as the solo developer of the system software for the RoadCrack road-survey vehicle.</p><p>The prototype vehicle was capable of imaging the road, processing and classifying cracks down to 1 mm resolution at 105 kmph.</p><p>The software interfaced with custom FPGA based image acquisition hardware, distributing the image data from industrial line-scan cameras via high speed frame grabbers and a network of 5+ Digital Alpha computers which performed the processing. Data was reported to a front-end control user interface in real-time.</p><p>Image processing code developed elsewhere in CSIRO extracted cracking and classified each image. Development predated contemporary machine learning algorithms and relied on classical computer vision techniques.</p><p>The opportunity to work on the RoadCrack project and the support of the crew at CSIRO was instrumental in kicking off my ongoing career in innovative, R&amp;D driven companies.</p><p>More details on RoadCrack at https://csiropedia.csiro.au/roadcrack-1999/ and check out a promo video at https://csiropedia.csiro.au/automated-pavement-crack-detection-and-classification-1994/</p>

item.title: Automated asset inspection with ML
item.description: <p>I tuned in for a particularly interesting presentation as part of Smart Cities Summit 2021 yesterday. Some amazing work being done by Moreton Bay Regional Council and Retina Visions on automated visual asset inspection. They are leveraging their existing garbage collection vehicles to acquire video footage of the road and roadside during their rounds, and processing that video to identify all kinds of maintenance issues.</p><p>From road defects including cracking to curbside rubbish to overhanging trees - all detected automatically and fed directly into the council asset management system and used to dispatch maintenance crews.</p><p>I also noted a great use of edge AI - to mitigate privacy issues, both faces and license plates are detected on the acquisition device and blurred as the footage is acquired. The redacted footage is then sent back to the cloud for the gruntier processing work of detecting and classifying the defect types. In this way itâ€™s possible to leverage the huge processing power in the cloud whilst ensuring that sensitive data never leaves the truck.</p><p>Itâ€™s a really inspiring example of a council embracing new technology to reduce costs and improve services for their community.</p>

item.title: Why is Machine Learning such a big deal for Computer Vision?
item.description: <p>Computer Vision - teaching computers to understand images - is a classically hard problem.&nbsp;</p><p>Why? Because computers donâ€™t see images at all - just numbers where humans have had millions of years to become great at seeing.</p><p>So why are modern Machine Learning techniques such a big deal for CV? It is now clear that basic image understanding can be reduced to a fuzzy pattern matching exercise and thatâ€™s where our current ML is at. And modern ML is a massive step up from where CV was only a decade ago.</p><p>Two, the reams of video data we are producing provide both the incentive and the means to solve the problem. CV can add value to video data produced in industries such as security, manufacturing and medicine by processing it quickly and efficiently, much cheaper than people can. The same data can be used to train the ML models to process it.</p><p>The killer app for ML for CV? Edge processing of video. Managing privacy concerns inherent with video recordings, and bandwidth issues to stream video to the cloud from remote sites both mean that processing video at the edge, before sending results to the cloud is a massive win.</p><p>My prediction: itâ€™s only going to get bigger.</p>

item.title: Beware of the cargo-cult
item.description: <p>Got a technical problem to solve? Analysing data? Machine learning! Deploying code? Spin up a Kubernetes cluster! Need a web app? Jump into React! Sharing information? item.title: Developers: don't make your life easy
item.description: <p>Software developers, your job *isnâ€™t* to make your work easy. Software development involves a lot of tradeoffs, and if your thought process is â€œwhatâ€™s the easiest way to solve this problem?â€, youâ€™re not going about it the right way.</p><p>Think longer term, bigger picture. Understand that all those fiddly little decisions you need to make day-to-day add up to significant impact on the customer, the team and ultimately the company.</p><p>If you hit a bug while looking for some other issue, figure out whatâ€™s going on and fix it! Think through those frustrating corner cases and deal with them, Expect things to fail and handle errors appropriately!</p><p>Day to day micro-decisions from engineers have a massive impact on customer experience, product quality, code quality, and ultimately on the company bottom-line.</p>

item.title: Step back to move forward
item.description: <p>When Iâ€™m called over to help out with a tricky problem in a complex software system, Iâ€™m typically hit with lots of detail on how the problem is manifesting. Typically my go-to response is â€œletâ€™s take a step backâ€...</p><p>In a lot of instances, issues that manifest in a very specific way are in fact symptoms of a larger scale problem, so itâ€™s important to put them in context. item.title: Remote - the future of work?
item.description: <p>When I, along with so many other professionals suddenly started working from home last year, I thought it would be awesome. And it certainly had its advantages - no commute, less interruptions, more flexibility to exercise &amp; spend family time. Many tech folk rejoiced and declared that this was the way we should all work, all the time.</p><p>But work-at-home is no panacea. Many people simply donâ€™t have the space / separation to do long term focussed work at home. Many have kids, family and house-mates around. Internet access varies wildly across cities and suburbs. Bad ergonomics can have a massive impact on peopleâ€™s health when they are subjected to them full time.</p><p>It is also considerably harder to collaborate effectively remotely. Even with instant messaging, teleconferencing, virtual whiteboards etc, the ease of collaboration that can be obtained standing around a whiteboard in a meeting cannot be matched.</p><p>Iâ€™m about to take my business out of the small space I have carved out at home and full time into a co-working space. Iâ€™m looking forward to the change of scene, the separation from family, the tea room, and yes, even talking to other occupants of the space!</p><p>Even the short commute is appealing - a little bookend to the working day.&nbsp;</p><p>Long term, Iâ€™d love to see companies experimenting with hybrid office/remote working setup. Where â€œremoteâ€ could mean home / paid co-work / or a satellite office. This could be a killer combination that balances flexibility &amp; lifestyle with employee health and in-person collaboration which is so important.</p><p>Also published on <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/remote-future-work-daniel-moore-/">LinkedIn</a></p>

item.title: Design review
item.description: <p>Significant pieces of engineering work can benefit greatly from design review. The review process can be as simple as an informal chat between peers or follow a formal process with a proposal document and written feedback or an in-person review session.</p><p>Design review is particularly valuable when a problem is highly constrained through user requirements or technical difficulty.</p><p>Design discussions often swing wildly between a number of proposals which all seem reasonable at first glance but are discounted due to various deficiencies with respect to requirements. Ensure the team feels empowered to challenge proposals, and not threatened by having their ideas challenged.&nbsp;</p><p>As a leader, prepare for your proposals to be found wanting by the team - it can hurt but if they come up with better proposals, youâ€™re winning.</p>

item.title: Communication is key
item.description: <p>Strong collaboration requires strong communication. Building a culture of strong, open communication is critical in the success of teams.</p><p>Good communication is clear &amp; concise - it gets to the point and stays on the point.&nbsp;</p><p>Good communication is correct and consistent - itâ€™s fine to not have all the answers, or be confident about something. Giving a solid answer may require some research and itâ€™s likely everyone will benefit from it.</p><p>Encourage participation in discussions, and ensure contributions are heard and considered.</p>

item.title: Code review
item.description: <p>A good code review process can greatly improve code quality while bringing significant benefits in engineering team culture.&nbsp;</p><p>At its most basic, code review helps catch errors that would otherwise have been missed by the author of a code change. Involving more senior engineers and/or those with more experience in a particular codebase or technique can catch higher level issues such as leaky abstractions, locking hierarchy or threading problems.</p><p>But just as importantly, code review can be used to encourage engineers to take responsibility for their work. Not just make something work, but think through what theyâ€™re doing, understand it, make a good change, and be prepared to defend it.</p><p>A team that can respectfully give feedback and even challenge each others work is a stronger team.</p><p></p>

item.title: The time / scope / quality tradeoff
item.description: <p>The tradeoff inherent between time, scope and quality is fundamental in Software Development. Pushing a team to â€œcrunchâ€ has diminishing returns, and whilst it can be justified occasionally, resentment will build up if itâ€™s used as a crutch for bad planning / unrealistic expectations.</p><p>Set pragmatic quality gates for different release types and stick to them. Involve engineers in the planning process to set realistic expectations for release dates, but accept that the more novel something is, the less certain the timeline will be.&nbsp;</p><p>If a release date is set in stone, accept that scope may need to be reduced to make the date, and make the call on what to cut early.</p><p>Respect the time / scope / quality tradeoff.</p>

item.title: Rigor in Software Development
item.description: <p>Different software systems require different levels of rigour applied in their development. Software running on a medical implant is life critical, heavily regulated, and requires the highest degree of rigour.</p><p>By contrast, software running a barebones minimum-viable-product for a nascent startup can be Rube-Goldberg-esque in structure, as long as it gets the job done.</p><p>Founders should carefully consider what their requirements and expectations are for the products they are building. Developing a system that is reliable, scalable, correct, testable, performant and maintainable software to solve complex problems requires a level of rigour.&nbsp;</p><p>Donâ€™t assume a development team will deliver on system requirements that havenâ€™t been specified.</p>

item.title: Attention to detail
item.description: <p>Attention to detail is critical in software development. Software is described as code, and computers execute the code as it is written, regardless of the intent of the developer.&nbsp;</p><p>In the best case, errors are picked up by the developers editor or compiler and can be rapidly fixed. Worst case, errors can lurk for years undetected, causing intermittent small failures, or eventually a critical failure.</p><p>When every character matters, it pays to â€œdot your iâ€™s and cross your tâ€™sâ€.&nbsp;</p>
